Posts.Title: And the good news continues... LuvRVing marymoir

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 04:43PM moondancer2 wrote: Hi HLB.  My TMs including ca27-29 have been accurate.  Was placed on letrozole a year ago and after a few months the TMs started a gradual decline.  They reached normal range five months ago, and now occasionally will drop a point.   My onc says not to be concerned if they rise a point or two as well, as its all part of a holding pattern.  Hope that helps.  Personally, I'm just happy to have TMs in the normal range for however long it lasts.   Hope letrozole works for you for a long time.  Karen
Posts.Title: A little concerned HLB HLB
How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2013 08:03AM moondancer2 wrote: Hi Donna7, I was diagnosed as stage IV from the get go, with innumerable metastases to all vertebra, both scapulae, humeri, femurs, sternum, cranium and facial bones, as well as left ankle and foot.  Had a lumpectomy, and numerous LCIS (all Grade 3) were found along surgical borders... no further surgery was done.  Have been on only letrozole and zometa.  Tumor markers steadily declined, and on the last PET scan there was no evidence of disease (NED).  Have been trying trying to figure out why the response to letrozole has been as good as it has, as the tumor was only 60% ER +.  Either bc is a total crapshoot, which I'm inclined to believe, or perhaps my change in diet may have helped.  Switched to an Atkins-like diet, cut out all sugar, and ate more avocados and tomato paste based dishes.  Have since found out that a substance isolated from avocado leaves, (but present in all parts of the avocado plant), stabilizes microtubules, which stops cell division specifically in breast cancer cells.  Could this have contributed?  Who knows? The locations of your metastases are sites that suggest it may be lobular carcinoma, and I seem to recall reading that ILC responds better to femara (letrozole) than other antihormonals.  Hope someone jumps in and corrects me if I'm wrong. Wishing you every success in your treatment!

Posts.Title: A few moments to de-stress for us all Chickadee K-Lo

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2014 12:25PM - edited Mar 2, 2014 03:39AM by moondancer2 This has to be the longest winter ever!!!  I too,am sick of winter!  We live in Wisconsin, and have had weeks on end of high temperatures in the single digits and teens.  The frost line is down to 8 feet in some places and the water lines are freezing in town.  People around here are getting excited about the prospect of having the temperature finally getting up to close to freezing a week from this Saturday!  (They are forecasting 31 degrees for Sat. March 8th.)  We have outside animals and it has been a real struggle keeping water tanks free from ice for our two horses and the group of milk goats, ...and hauling warm water to the chickens and buck.  So far they are doing well, and we haven't lost any of them... even the little two pound silkies (miniature chickens).   Knock on wood!  Hang in there... Spring is on its way...I hope.
Posts.Title: Winter blues raro chris1959

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 09:55AM - edited Mar 2, 2014 12:28PM by moondancer2 Raro...It is reassuring to know that there are others who are heartily sick of winter and more than ready for spring.   How neat that you've had silkies... you're right about being amazing little birds!  We have 5 in a flock of 19.  On really cold mornings, when I bring the chickens their warm water, the two little white silkies seem to say "Gang way!" and elbow their way through the flock to reach the water first and start drinking.  Makes me smile every time.  Silkies have such huge personalities tucked into such tiny bodies! They certainly hold their own in a flock of much larger birds, but yet are docile enough to sit on your lap to be petted.
Posts.Title: Winter blues raro chris1959
